Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Behavior-Based Stochastic Traffic Flow Modeling for Intersection Safety Improvement

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will investigate driver behavior at signalized intersections and derive sophisticated traffic flow models aimed at intersection safety improvement. Intersection safety has long been a national concern, partly due to the lack of understanding of complicated driving behaviors, especially decision-making mechanisms present when drivers face signal phase changes. This research tackles this issue by conducting a comprehensive investigation of driver decision-making at signalized intersections and, using insights from these investigations, developing a stochastic traffic flow model for such interrupted flow situations. Through the integration of the developed traffic flow model with connected vehicle technologies (specifically, V2X), the developed traffic flow model can be used to quantify the safety performance of signalized intersections, identify emerging hazardous situations, and contribute to the development of driver-assistance and intersection-accident-avoidance technologies. Furthermore, the outcomes from this research will create opportunities for students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, through educational and research opportunities in transportation engineering. It will also provide opportunities for college students, traffic engineers, and K-12 faculty and students through curriculum development, educational modules, and creation of pathways between high school and college, as well as college and graduate school.

The objectives of this research include: 1) investigating complicated driving behaviors and the inner mechanisms of drivers' decision-making at signalized intersections through the analysis of vehicular trajectory data extracted from video images and 2) developing a stochastic traffic flow model to describe complicated driving behaviors and predict potential traffic conflicts at signalized intersections by considering the stochastic nature of drivers decision-making when facing signal phase changes under varying circumstances. This research will contribute to the theoretical development of traffic flow models. These traffic flow models will be able to describe complicated driving behaviors and estimate traffic conflicts at signalized intersections, both of which are absent from most other traffic flow models. Furthermore, this research is expected to contribute significantly to the improvement of intersection safety. This research will build a foundation for the future development of dynamic systems for alerting drivers of emerging hazards and helping to avoid intersection accidents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intersection safety has long been a national concern, partly due to the lack of understanding of complicated driving behaviors when drivers face signal phase changes. This research tackles this issue by conducting an investigation of driver decision-making at signalized intersections and developing traffic flow models for interrupted traffic. In particular, this research proposes innovative methods to identify the emerging and impending hazardous situations including red-light running (RLR) violations and potential traffic conflicts, which essentially can be used to quantify the safety level of an intersection. The research first estimates the drivers' decision to stop-or-run by developing a model to identify yellow-light running (YLR) and RLR cases using high-resolution data. Then combining with statistical models, this research develops a binary logistical regression model to predict drivers' complicated decisions at signalized intersections. Furthermore, due to the rare events nature of RLR, a modified rare events logistic regression model was developed for RLR prediction. At the end, this research develops an intersection safety evaluation system which evaluates the overall intersection safety based on a combination of the potential traffic conflicts and RLR cases. The proposed system has been applied to intersections in Anaheim, CA.

This research is expected to contribute significantly to the improvement of intersection safety. In addition, the proposed traffic flow-based safety evaluation models can be integrated with the connected vehicle technologies (i.e. V2X) to assist automatically quantifying the safety performance of signalized intersections and identifying emerging hazardous situations, and to further contribute to the development of driver-assistance and intersection-accident-avoidance technologies.

Broader Impacts: As a RUI research project, significant efforts of this research have been devoted to creating broader impacts on students, particularly underrepresented groups. The research first uses the current facilities at Cal Poly Pomona (CPP) including state-of-the-art simulation and visualization facilities, to design educational modules, which benefit both faculty and students in a number of courses including Highway Design, Transportation Engineering, Traffic Engineering, Traffic Flow Analysis, Traffic Safety, and Transportation Systems Simulation. Additionally, the research has developed an early draft platform to facilitate active learning and teaching in Transportation Engineering. Most importantly, this research expands capabilities in Transportation Engineering education and research by enhancing existing pathways and creating new pathway for faculty and students. Specifically, this project has provided educational opportunities in Transportation Engineering for K-12 faculty and students through seminars, workshops, and training sessions. Secondly, this program has offered opportunities for undergraduate students to conduct research in Transportation through CPP's Office of Undergraduate Research (OUR). This helps initiate a nascent Ph.D. pathway from California State University (CSU) campuses to the University of California (UC) campuses by assisting CPP students to gain more opportunities to pursue a Ph.D. degree at UC. Finally, this project has been working with OUR and the Maximizing Engineering Potential (MEP) to provide more research opportunities for underrepresented engineering students.
